qas.question: Did the followers of Meletius obey the guidelines of Nicaea?
What was Athanasius accused of planning against the Arians?
What was the verdict of the accusation?
Who was he accused of harming?
Who did obey the guidelines of Nicaea?
Who claimed Constantinople would cut off grain supplies?
Constantinople was afraid they wouldn't receive grains from whom?
What exile is in modern day France?

context: Athanasius's first problem lay with <b5_0>Meletius<b5_0/> of Lycopolis and his followers, who had <a0_0>failed to abide<a0_0/> by the First Council of Nicaea. That council also <a3_0>anathematized<a3_0/> Arius. Accused of mistreating <a4_0>Arians and Meletians<a4_0/>, Athanasius answered those charges at a gathering of bishops in Tyre, the First Synod of Tyre, in 335. There, Eusebius of Nicomedia and other supporters of Arius deposed Athanasius. On 6 November, both sides of the dispute met with Emperor Constantine I in Constantinople. At that meeting, the <b7_0>Arians<b7_0/> claimed <b6_0>Athanasius<b6_0/> would try to <a1_0>cut off essential Egyptian grain<a1_0/> supplies to Constantinople. He <a2_0>was found guilty<a2_0/>, and sent into exile to <b8_0>Augusta Treverorum<b8_0/> in Gaul (now Trier in Germany).
